qas.question: What was the name of the Luftwaffe plan to invade Britain?
How many people died in the bombing of Hamburg?
What was the date of the bombing of Hamburg?
Who was the leader of the Luftwaffe?

context: The bombing failed to demoralise the British into surrender or significantly damage the war economy. The eight months of bombing never seriously hampered British production and the war industries continued to operate and expand. The Blitz was only authorised when the Luftwaffe had failed to meet preconditions for a 1940 launch of <a0_0>Operation Sea Lion<a0_0/>, the provisionally planned German invasion of Britain. By May 1941 the threat of an invasion of Britain had passed, and <a3_0>Hitler<a3_0/>'s attention had turned to Operation Barbarossa in the East. In comparison to the later Allied bombing campaign against Germany, the Blitz resulted in relatively few casualties; the British bombing of Hamburg in <a2_0>July 1943<a2_0/> inflicted some <a1_0>42,000<a1_0/> civilian deaths, about the same as the entire Blitz.
